fullProgramDescription: The undergraduate major in Management Science and Engineering (MS&E) provides students with an understanding of how individuals, organizations, and societies make decisions, and the means to analyze and improve the decision-making process. The program is designed to give students a broad understanding of the field, as well as the ability to apply analytical and computational techniques to real-world problems.
shortProgramDescription: The MS&E major prepares students to address complex problems in a wide range of fields, including business, government, and non-profit organizations, by providing them with a strong foundation in analytical and computational techniques.
classHighlights: Foundational Courses: Students take courses in Probability and Statistics (MS&E 120), Economics (ECON 1, 3), and Introduction to Modeling and Analysis (MS&E 101).
Mathematical and Computational Foundations: Students complete courses in calculus (MATH 19-21, 51), linear algebra (MATH 51, 113), and differential equations (MATH 52, 53, 131A).
Core MS&E Courses: Students take courses in Deterministic Models (MS&E 211), Stochastic Models (MS&E 221), and Optimization (MS&E 212).
Engineering and Economic Analysis: Students learn to analyze and optimize systems, and understand the economic and financial implications of their decisions.
Data-Driven Decision Making: Students learn to work with data, including data analysis, data visualization, and machine learning.
Electives and Specializations: Students can choose from a range of electives and specializations, including courses in data science, artificial intelligence, and energy systems.
learningOutcomes: Apply analytical and computational techniques to real-world problems
Understand the decision-making process and how to analyze and improve it
Work effectively with data, including data analysis, data visualization, and machine learning
Analyze and optimize systems, and understand the economic and financial implications of decisions
Communicate complex ideas effectively to both technical and non-technical audiences
additionalInformation: Students declare through the School of Engineering. The major requires a minimum of 11 courses in the major department, as well as additional math, science, and engineering requirements.
